I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
to Mongolia for additional financing of the Fourth Health Sector Development Project.1 
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  the  current  project  in  2010. 2  It  was 
2. 
designed  to  improve  health  sector  efficiency,  governance,  and  drug  safety,  focusing  on  three 
key areas: hospital services in Ulaanbaatar, human resources development, and a drug safety 
regime.  The  additional  financing  will  significantly  expand  the  output  of  the  current  project,3 
establishing  a  demonstration  multifunction  general  hospital  in  Songinohairkhan  district  of 
Ulaanbaatar.4 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

Under  the  current  project,  establishment  of  a  demonstration  multifunction  general 
3. 
hospital  was  planned  in  Songinohairkhan,  the  poorest  district  of  Ulaanbaatar,  to  include 
renovating and expanding the infrastructure, equipping the hospital, and introducing innovative 
management  systems  (original  hospital  output).5 Civil  works  under  this  output  are  planned  to 
start  in  the  spring  of  2013.  In  May  2011,  the  Parliament  amended  the  health  law,  requiring 
general  hospitals  to  provide  at  least  seven  specialized  medical  services. 6  This  substantial 
increase in mandated standards for delivery of health services by general hospitals means that 
the  funding  allocated  to  the  hospital  output  under  the  current  project  is  no  longer  adequate  to 
achieve the stated output. To accommodate the required upgrading, and considering the poor 
state  of  the  existing  infrastructure,  the  government  concluded  that  it  was  more  efficient  to 
construct  a  new  hospital  in  the  same  location  than  to  continue  with  the  original  plan  of 
renovating and rehabilitating the old hospital complex. The government has therefore requested 
additional financing to support the proposed project expansion. The government aims to use the 
new  demonstration  general  hospital  as  a  model  to  be  replicated  in  the  nine  districts  of 
Ulaanbaatar. 7  This  300-bed  hospital 8  will  include  modern  features  such  as  surgical  and 
maternity services; adequate diagnostic and laboratory capacity; integrated management of out- 
and  inpatient  departments;  model  nursing  care;  proper  medical  waste management;  adequate

4. 
Hospital  infrastructure  in  Mongolia  is  generally  poor.  Moreover,  the  rapid  population 
growth  in  Ulaanbaatar  requires  continuous  investments  in  hospitals.  The  expanded  output 
targeted at construction of the demonstration multifunction general hospital is an integral part of 
the broader effort to reform hospitals being supported under the current project. As part of the 
current project, a hospital policy and a strategic hospital development plan to restructure public 
and private hospitals are expected to be approved by the cabinet in 2012. The broader financial 
implications and funding requirements of a modern public hospital network are analyzed and are 
part  of  the  impending  strategic  plan.  A  detailed  operational  plan  including  financial,  human 
resources, and managerial aspects, is being developed for the demonstration hospital, with the 
assistance of the World Health Organization (WHO). The operational costs of providing higher-
quality care through the demonstration hospital are projected to increase from the current level. 
Actual costs will depend on factors such as the staff–bed ratio, higher wages to motivate staff, 
and  proper  budgeting  for  maintenance  services  and  capital  depreciation.10 Recent  and  future 
trends  in  Mongolia’s  public  finance  suggest  that  additional  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M) 
costs for the demonstration hospital can be comfortably financed by rising public revenues. 
 
5. 
Total  out-of-pocket  health  expenditures  are  estimated  at  17%–30%  of  total  health 
expenditures  in  Mongolia,  which  is  in  line  with  the  WHO’s  guideline  of  not  exceeding  30%. 
About  80%  of  the  population  is  covered  by  health  insurance  and  about  50%  of  hospital 
revenues are paid for by direct state funding. This contributes to accessibility and affordability. 
Nevertheless, equity in accessing health care for the poorer segments of the population remains 
a  challenge,  as  some  of  these  individuals  do  not  have  health  insurance.  In  addition,  out-of-
pocket  payments  are  the  rule  for  those  who  are  insured.  ADB  is  addressing  equity  issues 
through three ongoing projects11 and the reform of the citizens’ health insurance law promoted 
by the Social Sectors Support Program.12

Implementation  progress. Implementation progress is satisfactory. The current 
project had achieved 30% of cumulative physical progress against 32% elapsed 
time  by  September  2012.  Cumulative  contract  awards  and  disbursement  are

Safeguard  compliance. Safeguard requirements are being met. The grievance 
redress mechanism under the environmental management plan was established 
from  the  start  of  the  current  project  and  no  complaint  has  been  received.  The 
environmental  management  plan  was  updated  and  approved  by  ADB.  The  first

(iv)  Management  of  risks.  Risks  are  being  managed  successfully.  The  report  and 
recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  ADB  Board  of  Directors  for  the  current 
project identified major risks as (a) resistance to change from key health workers' 
groups  and  government  agencies,  and  the  community;  and  (b)  lack  of 
government  and  community  support  for  hospital  reform.  No  resistance  has 
emerged, although hospital reforms were discussed in broad fora involving many 
stakeholders,  and  information  campaigns  were  organized.  Agencies  such  as 
GASI,  the  State  Property  Committee,  and  professional  associations  have  been 
keen  to  actively  participate  in  the  discussion  on  hospital  reform.  Mitigation 
measures  proposed  in  the  risk  assessment  and  risk  management  plan  of  the 
current project are being implemented and potential risks have not materialized.  
Project  performance  rating. The current project is rated on track in the project

(v) 

 
7. 
The design of the current project was relevant and consistent with previous initiatives to 
reform the Mongolian health sector in line with the National Development Strategy to 2021 and 
the government’s Health Sector Master Plan (2006–2015). The current project focuses on three 
key  areas:  (i)  hospital  services  in  Ulaanbaatar,  (ii)  human  resources  development,  and  (iii)  a 
drug  safety  regime.  The  current  project,  enhanced  by  the  additional  financing  (the  overall 
project),  will  improve  governance  in  the  sector  by  improving  public  investment  planning, 
providing  decent  and  efficient  hospital  services,  protecting  the  population  against  counterfeit 
and  substandard  drugs,  and  facilitating  public  access  to  information  on  hospital  performance 
and drug safety. At the same time, hospital reforms give the government a unique opportunity to 
establish  public–private  collaboration  for  the  benefit  of  the  population.  The  overall  project  will 
deliver tangible benefits to women by ensuring their active participation in institutional processes 
to reform hospitals and drug safety. 
 

3 

 

 4 

 

The  additional  financing  is  considered  to  meet  the  four  eligibility  criteria  for  additional 
8. 
financing.13 First, ADB reviewed the current project in April 2012 and confirmed the satisfactory 
performance  and  that  no  significant  changes  in  approaches  and  methodologies  were 
envisioned.14 Accordingly, the current project remains technically feasible, economically viable, 
and  financially  sound.  Second,  the  government  accords  high  priority  to  the  current  project  as 
proposed  to  be  expanded  through  the  additional  financing.  The  demonstration  hospital 
represents a concrete step in implementing the 2011 amended health law, as acknowledged by 
the government’s request for additional financing. Third, the project outcome remains the same, 
while the output related to the demonstration hospital, supported by the additional financing, will 
be  enhanced  and  remains  consistent  with  the  project’s  development  objectives.  Fourth,  the 
expanded project and its outcome are consistent with the current country partnership strategy, 
2012–2016, 15  which  emphasizes  social  development  through  efficient  delivery  of  health 
services.  
 
9. 
The additional financing modality is highly relevant as the modification in respect of the 
demonstration hospital output will make it possible to meet the objectives of the current project 
in light of the amended  health law requiring higher standards for general hospitals. The Asian 
Development  Fund  loan  modality  is  relevant  to  finance  major  infrastructure  rather  than  using 
Asian  Development  Fund  grant  funding  as  in  the  current  project.  The  current  project 
implementation  arrangements  (i.e.,  project  steering  committee,  implementing  agency,  and 
project  implementation  unit)  are  effective  and  ensure  a  high  degree  of  readiness  in 
implementing  the  additional  financing.  The  development  of  the  hospital  policy  and  strategic 
hospital  development  plan  under  the  current  project  and  continuing  under  the  overall  project 
provides  a  framework  for  later  replication  of  the  demonstration  general  hospital  to  be 
established under the additional financing. The enhanced model character of the new hospital 
will reinforce its demonstration effect and will provide a strong incentive for reforming hospitals 
in Mongolia as promoted under the current project.   
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

10. 
The  impact  and  outcome  statements  of  the  current  project  will  be  retained.  The 
expected  impact of  the  overall  project  will be to  improve the health status  of  the  Mongolian 
population,  including  the  poor.  The  outcome  will  be  improved  health  sector  efficiency, 
governance, and drug safety.  An outcome and an impact indicator will be added to reflect the 
strengthened hospital sector. The outputs will also be retained, except for the indicators of the 
original output 3 related to establishment of the demonstration hospital. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

11. 

The 12 outputs of the overall project are regrouped under three components: 
(i) 

Component  1:  Strengthened  hospital  services  in  Ulaanbaatar.  The  overall 
project will assist the government in preparing a hospital development policy and 
strategic  plan  for  Ulaanbaatar  (output  1),  operationalize  a  hospital  capital 
planning  system  (output  2),  turn  the  Songinohairkhan  district  hospital  of 
Ulaanbaatar  into  a  multifunction  general  hospital  (output  3),  and  improve  the 
hospital governance system (output 4).

A. 

Economic and Financial 

Technical 
 
16. 
The technical aspects of the overall project are sound. A systematic approach is applied 
to  development  of  the  hospital  policy  and  the  strategic  hospital  development  plan  to  ensure 
stakeholder participation, operational feasibility, and financial sustainability. A reputable design 
firm  will  update  the  preliminary  hospital  site  plan,  including  access,  parking,  and  greenery,  in 
line with improved construction and operational standards. The hospital will be managed by the 
government with support from the private sector. 
 
B. 
 
17. 
The  economic  analysis  evaluated  the  economic  viability  of  the  overall  project.  The 
analysis covers the macroeconomic context so as to review the potential for the government to 
continue  to  finance  the  project  activities  in  the  longer  term,  following  project  completion.  The 
analysis  covers  the  quantifiable  economic  costs  and  benefits  for  the  improved  hospital 
component  and  provides  qualitative  analysis  of  the  drug  safety  component.  The  economic 
impact  of  unsafe  medicine  is  difficult  to  quantify  because  there  are  a  number  of  unknown 
variables. Using conservative estimates of project implementation, the baseline results show an 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  11.95%,  reflecting  substantial  unquantifiable 
economic benefits. The EIRR was tested through sensitivity analysis using a 20% decrease in 
economic  benefits  as  the  worst-case  scenario  for  each  of  the  economic  benefits  relating  to 
hospital  efficiency  savings,  out-of-pocket  cost  savings  for  patients,  and  reduction  in  projected 
productivity  improvements.  Under  these  conservative  assumptions,  the  EIRRs  range  from 
7.59% to 11.01%; hence, the project is considered economically viable.21

The  overall  project  has  no  revenue-earning  component;  hence,  financial  cost  benefits 
18. 
were  not  analyzed  as  part  of  the  financial  analysis.  The  MOH,  Ulaanbaatar  City  Health 
Department, and GASI will contribute counterpart funding and bear the project’s O&M costs. A 
fiscal analysis indicated that the annual average contribution of the MOH to the overall project is 
0.5% of the health sector annual budget. The annual O&M cost, to be borne by GASI, will not 
exceed  2.0%  of  its  current  revenue.  Additional  O&M  costs  required  by  the  Ulaanbaatar  City 
health  organizations  for  the  demonstration  hospital  will  be  about  0.6%  of  its  total  annual 
expenditure.  The  counterpart  funding  and  O&M  costs  are  considered  both  financially 
sustainable  and  affordable.  A  financial  management  assessment  concluded  that  the  MOH  is 
experienced in managing ADB projects and is prepared for project implementation. 
 
C. 
 
19. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  MOH  for  the  additional  financing  activities.  The  specific  policy 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 20). The MOH 
has  been  a  partner  of  ADB  since  1991.  The  project  implementation  unit  established  for  the 
current  project,  which  is  performing  satisfactorily,  will  continue  to  handle  all  project  financial 
matters, procurement, and recruitment of consultants, supervised by the MOH. The government 
through  the  MOH  will  ensure  that  civil  works  supervisory  responsibility  will  be  assigned  to  the 
firm  in  charge  of  designing  the  new  hospital.  The  Ulaanbaatar  Mayor’s  Office  recently 
underwent  a  procurement  and  financial  capacity  assessment  for  the  Urban  Transport 
Development  Investment  Program,  which  concluded  that  the  Municipality  of  Ulaanbaatar’s 
financial management, procurement, reporting, and monitoring systems are satisfactory. 22 
 
D. 
 
20. 
The  overall  project  will  directly  benefit  more  than  260,000  mostly  poor  residents  of  the 
Songinohairkhan  district  of  Ulaanbaatar  by  improving  district  hospital  services.  Additional 
financing  will  improve  the  range  and  quality  of  hospital  services  provided  to  the  population 
beyond  the  services  that  were  planned  under  the  current  project.  The  overall  project  will  also 
benefit  the  entire  population  of  Mongolia  by  improving  access  to  safer  drugs,  and,  in  the  long 
run,  will  improve  allocative  efficiency  in  the  health  sector  by  optimizing  the  use  of  hospital 
services  and  improving  the  return  on  future  investment  in  hospitals.  Poverty  and  health  are 
strongly related, and better health services are not only a social goal but also a prerequisite to 
economic development. Therefore, improved health care will expand the economic opportunities 
of the whole population, including the poor. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy 
has been updated to reflect the additional financing component. 
 
21. 
The  current  project  and  the  additional  financing  are  classified  as  effective  gender 
mainstreaming. In Mongolia, the health status of the population is highly differentiated by sex. 
The  male  mortality  rate  is  high,  and  male  life  expectancy  is  low  compared  with  females,  due 
primarily to unhealthy lifestyle habits such as smoking and heavy drinking. Women comprise the 
majority of users and providers of the health care system in Mongolia, and 20% of households 
in urban areas in Mongolia are headed by women.23 Women provide the majority of care for ill 
family members. The vast majority of the country’s total medical staff consists of women (82%).
